description: From late Middle English proprietee, propretee, propriete (“ownership”), borrowed from Anglo-Norman propreté, Middle French proprieté, from Latin proprietās. By surface analysis, proper +‎ -iety. Doublet of property.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The particular character or essence of someone or something; individuality. [15th–20th c.]
(now rare) A piece of land owned by someone; someone's property. [from 16th c.]
(obsolete) More generally, something owned by someone; a possession. [16th–19th c.]
examples: I was fearful of giving You a very sensible Disgust, in making You seem the Propriety of one Man, when You know Yourself ordained for the Comfort and Refreshment of Multitudes.

entries.meaning: The fact of possessing something; ownership. [from 16th c.]
examples: This ſweet word, I will be your God, implies, 1. Propriety, that all that is in God ſhall be ours; his love ours, his Spirit ours, his mercy ours.

entries.meaning: (now rare) Correct language or pronunciation. [from 17th c.]
Suitability, fitness; the quality of being appropriate. [from 18th c.]
examples: I find such a pleasure, sir, in obeying your commands, that I take care to observe them without ever debating their propriety.

entries.meaning: (often in the plural) Correctness in behaviour and morals; good manners, seemliness. [from 19th c.]
